verses.text: Jotham was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jerushah, the daughter of Zadok.
verses.comment: Jotham's lineage emphasizes the continuity of David's line and the importance of legitimate authority, showing faithfulness to God's covenant with David. This continuity is ultimately fulfilled in Christ as the eternal King (Luke 1:32-33).

verses.text: He did what was right in the eyes of the LORD, just as his father Uzziah had done; but he did not enter the temple of the LORD. However, the people continued acting corruptly.
verses.comment: Jotham is praised for his righteousness, but he wisely avoids his father's error of unlawfully entering the temple (see 2 Chr. 26:16-21). His restraint points to the necessity of respecting holy boundaries, foreshadowing the roles of priest, king, and prophet united in Christ. Though the king is righteous, the people's corruption shows the need for deep spiritual renewal, which is ultimately brought through sanctifying grace.

verses.text: He built the upper gate of the house of the LORD and did much work on the wall of Ophel.
verses.comment: Jotham's work on the city and the LORD's house demonstrates concern for the worship life and security of Jerusalem. Building and protecting sacred space reflects the priority of worship in the life of God's people, akin to building up the Church (see Matt. 16:18).

verses.text: He also built towns in the hill country of Judah, and strongholds and towers in the forests.
verses.comment: The expansion of fortifications and settlements shows practical leadership and care for the nation. Spiritually, the building of strongholds invites reflection on the strength and protection found in God's House and sacramental life.

verses.text: He fought with the king of the Ammonites and prevailed against them. The Ammonites that year gave him one hundred talents of silver, ten thousand cors of wheat, and ten thousand of barley. The Ammonites paid him the same in the second and third years.
verses.comment: Victory over the Ammonites and receipt of tribute demonstrates God's favor and the blessings that come with faithfulness. This foresees the gathering of nations under God's Anointed King, hinting at the worldwide Church (see Ps. 2:8).

verses.text: So Jotham became powerful because he set his ways before the LORD his God.
verses.comment: Jotham's success is rooted in his steadfastness before God. Righteousness and humble obedience bring blessing and spiritual fruit, a theme fulfilled in Christ, who fully does the Father's will. The spiritual life grows strong by adherence to right doctrine and divine worship.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Jotham, all his wars and his ways, are written in the Book of the Kings of Israel and Judah.
verses.comment: References to other records show a careful tradition of preserving sacred history. This careful transmission of God's dealings with His people is foundational for understanding the lineage leading to Christ (Matt. 1:1-16).

verses.text: He was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he reigned sixteen years in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: This verse repeats the details given in verse 1, a common feature in Hebrew history highlighting the stability and continuity of legitimate succession—tracing the role of divinely appointed leadership that ultimately points to Christ.

verses.text: Jotham rested with his fathers, and they buried him in the city of David. Ahaz his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: The mention of the burial in the city of David highlights the importance of Davidic descent. The transition to Ahaz further connects the chain of succession leading to the Messiah. God's faithfulness to His promises continues, and the visible sign of God’s covenant people is preserved throughout history.
